results.adx_keywords: internal-storyline-no;Inflation (Economics);Economic Conditions and Trends;Prices (Fares, Fees and Rates);Currency;US Dollar (Currency);Argentina
results.byline: By Jack Nicas, Ana Lankes and Sebastián López Brach
results.title: Think 9% Inflation Is Bad? Try 90%.
results.abstract: With the world grappling with rising prices, a tour through Argentina reveals that years of inflation can give rise to a truly bizarre economy.

media.caption: Argentina has dealt with rapidly rising prices for much of the past 50 years. People have been left with little idea of how much things should cost.

results.adx_keywords: Midterm Elections (2022);Presidential Election of 2024;United States Politics and Government;Content Type: Personal Profile;Politics and Government;Polls and Public Opinion;Cheney, Liz;Cheney, Dick;Hageman, Harriet;Republican Party;Cheyenne (Wyo);Wyoming
results.title: Liz Cheney Is Ready to Lose. But She’s Not Ready to Quit.
results.abstract: The Republican says her crusade to stop Donald J. Trump will continue — even if she loses her primary next week. Restoring a “very sick” G.O.P. will take years, she says, “if it can be healed.”

media.caption: Representative Liz Cheney with supporters in Cheyenne, Wyo.
media.copyright: Stephen Speranza for The New York Times

results.adx_keywords: Inflation Reduction Act of 2022;Health Insurance and Managed Care;Global Warming;Drugs (Pharmaceuticals);Prices (Fares, Fees and Rates);Medicare;United States Politics and Government;Biden, Joseph R Jr;Senate;Democratic Party
results.title: Senate Passes Climate, Health and Tax Bill, With All Republicans Opposed
results.abstract: The vote was a major victory for President Biden and Democrats, who are battling to maintain their slim House and Senate majorities in November’s midterm congressional elections.

media.caption: Democrats scaled back the legislation, which appeared dead just weeks ago, and rebranded it as the Inflation Reduction Act.
media.copyright: Tom Brenner for The New York Times

results.adx_keywords: Babies and Infants;Adoptions;Abortion;Child Abandonment;Roe v Wade (Supreme Court Decision);Safe Haven Baby Boxes (Nonprofit);Indiana;United States
results.title: Drop Box for Babies: Conservatives Promote a Way to Give Up Newborns Anonymously
results.abstract: After Roe, groups are seeking to expand safe haven laws, which allow women to surrender babies with minimal interference. But these laws pose their own problems.

media.caption: It looks like a library book drop, but it’s really a place for parents to surrender their newborns.
media.copyright: Kaiti Sullivan for The New York Times

results.adx_keywords: your-feed-science;Monkeypox;Drugs (Pharmaceuticals);Smallpox;Shortages;Food and Drug Administration;United States
results.title: There’s Just One Drug to Treat Monkeypox. Good Luck Getting It.
results.abstract: Doctors who want to prescribe tecovirimat, or Tpoxx, must navigate a gantlet of bureaucratic hurdles that experts say could be quickly lifted.

media.caption: Tecovirimat, also called Tpoxx, which treats monkeypox, is designated an “investigational drug,” which federal health officials say means it cannot be released from the national stockpile without a series of convoluted steps.

results.adx_keywords: Midterm Elections (2022);United States Politics and Government;Political Advertising;Primaries and Caucuses;Cheney, Liz;Cheney, Dick;Trump, Donald J;Wyoming
results.title: Dick Cheney excoriates Trump in an ad for his daughter Liz Cheney.
results.abstract: The one-minute ad landed with a bang on social media, but in Wyoming, it is highly unlikely to sway any significant number of voters in Ms. Cheney’s favor.

media.caption: “I proudly voted for my daughter,” former Vice President Dick Cheney said in a new ad for Representative Liz Cheney’s re-election campaign. “I hope you will, too.”

results.title: Archie Battersbee, Gravely Ill 12-Year-Old, Dies After Removal of Life Support
results.abstract: The boy’s family had made several legal appeals to keep him on a ventilator, but judges in Britain sided with doctors in finding that he had no hope of recovery.

results.adx_keywords: Deaths (Obituaries);Solitary Confinement;Books and Literature;Murders, Attempted Murders and Homicides;Coronavirus (2019-nCoV);Woodfox, Albert;Louisiana State Penitentiary
results.title: Albert Woodfox, Survivor of 42 Years in Solitary Confinement, Dies at 75
results.abstract: His term in solitary was perhaps the longest in American history. He described how he kept his sanity, and dignity, in an acclaimed memoir.

media.caption: Albert Woodfox after his release from prison in 2016. A federal judge said there was nothing “remotely comparable in the annals of American jurisprudence” to Mr. Woodfox’s 42 years in solitary confinement.
media.copyright: Bryan Tarnowski for The New York Times

results.title: Major Indiana Employers Criticize State’s New Abortion Law
results.abstract: The drug company Eli Lilly said it “will be forced” to look outside the state for employment growth. The engine maker Cummins said the law will “impede our ability to attract and retain top talent.”

media.caption: Eli Lilly’s corporate headquarters in Indianapolis.

results.title: Alabama City Moves to Dissolve Police Department Over Racist Text
results.abstract: Leaders of Vincent, Ala., suspended the chief and assistant police chief after a screenshot circulated on social media showing the text message.

media.caption: The City Council in Vincent, Ala., held an emergency meeting on Thursday and took steps to disband its police department.

results.title: Consumers will benefit from lower utility bills and cheaper home upgrades, energy experts say.
results.abstract: The Inflation Reduction Act includes tax deductions for energy-efficient home upgrades and a tax credit for electric vehicles.

media.caption: A neighborhood in Austin, Tex., where many homes are equipped with rooftop solar panels. The bill passed by the Senate on Sunday would allow households that are installing solar to deduct 30 percent of the cost from their taxes.
media.copyright: Tamir Kalifa for The New York Times

results.title: They Made History at Alabama. But Football Stardom Had a Price.
results.abstract: At least four fixtures of Alabama’s great teams of the 1960s had chronic traumatic encephalopathy, or C.T.E., at their deaths. Researchers expect it in other players, too.

results.abstract: Sharhea Wade was ready to forget about Stevenson Boyce, whom she met on Hinge, because he twice canceled their first date. But soon after a third (successful) attempt, she was ready to marry him.

results.adx_keywords: Black People;United States Defense and Military Forces;Hiring and Promotion;United States Politics and Government;Segregation and Desegregation;Langley, Michael E;United States Marine Corps;United States Africa Command
results.title: After 246 Years, Marine Corps Gives 4 Stars to a Black Officer
results.abstract: Gen. Michael E. Langley is the first Black person to attain the highest rank in the corps, whose most senior leadership had until now consisted entirely of white men.
des_facet: United States Defense and Military Forces

media.caption: Gen. Michael E. Langley had his new rank insignia pinned on his uniform by his stepmother, Ola Langley, and his father, Willie C. Langley, a retired Air Force master sergeant, during his promotion ceremony on Saturday.
media.copyright: Kenny Holston for The New York Times
